1.content:
Detective Jack Crown looked from the list of missing Fairy Tale characters up to his partner, Jill Pail, and back down at the list again. How could so many people go missing? It didn't make any sense. Someone had to be behind this whole fiasco and Jack was determined to find out who.

"Where should we start?" Jill asked him, already flipping through the missing persons reports. "That list is pretty long."

"I know," Jack agreed and sighed. He didn't know where to start. Any one of them was going to be a chore. Not only did they have to look for clues, but they had to try and restore the order to the Tales that had gone awry without their heroes.

"This is going to take a while."

Jack decided to start with...
1.title: Preface

choices: They head off to talk to the Woodsman
They go see the Big Bad Wolf
Go to the woods to look for clues
11.content:
"All right, we should probably start with Little Red," Jill said, gathering her files and stuffing them into a briefcase. She stood up, ready to go.

"Let's not be hasty!" Jack said, holding up his hands. "Why her? I need a good reason."

Jill looked at him, unamused. "Well for starters, without Little Red to come along and inspire the Woodsman to rid the world of the Big Bad Wolf, who isn't actually that bad of a guy, let me just say..."

"Is there a point here?"

Jill scoffed. "I'm getting to it."

"Well get to it a little quicker."

"Okay, fine," Jill crossed her arms over her chest. "Because the Woodsman isn't coming, Granny's sitting nice and cozy in the Big Bad Wolf's stomach. If we don't do something quick, she'll start being digested. And that's not pretty."

Jack paused for only a second to think about it.

"Good enough for me."
11.title: Digested Granny

choices: Sure, I could use the exercise
No thanks, my soap opera is on now
111.content:
So Jack and Jill headed off to find the Woodsman. After a few minutes of walking through the dense forest they came upon a very celestial looking log cabin. Jack led the way to the front door. He took a quick look and Jill, then knocked. Some rustling can be heard from inside the cabin. Finally the door pops open and staring back at the two sleuths was something they weren't expecting.

"May I help you?" asked a tall, bearded man. He looked sort of like The Woodsman, but something was amiss. This man was the same height as The Woodsman, had the same thick, black beard, and even wore the same clothing. But this man did not possess the cut, chiseled physique that The Woodsman had. Simply put, this man was fat.

"Ummm, yeah," Jill said.

"We're looking for The Woodsman," Jack said. "Ha..Have you seen him?"

The bearded man laughed in response. "Seen him? I am him! What, do you want an autograph or something? You know, once upon a time I saved this old lady from..."

"No, thank you, we aren't autograph seekers," Jill said. "Actually, we need your help Mr. Woodsman."

"You need some trees felled? A cabin built?" The Woodsman asked.

"No," Jill answered.

"Actually, we're looking for somebody," Jack said. "A Miss Hood, Little Red Riding. We'd like to ask her grandma if she's seen her, since she's her only known living relative, but..."

"But she's currently in the Big Bad Wolf's belly? Sheesh, that wolf never learns. So lemme guess, you want me to save the grandma? Again?"

"Yeah," Jack and Jill replied.

"The faster the better," Jill said.

The Woodsman thought for a moment, then answered...
111.title: T. Woodsman

choices: To the Big Bad Wolf!
To the Forest!
1111.content:
"Sure, I could use the excercise," said the Woodsman. Stepping around Jack he lifted his cloak off of a metal hook that clinged to the wooden wall, and picked up his woodsman's axe from a wooden umbrella stand that stood rigid by the door. "I don't go nowhere without it," he added, noticing Jill's odd look and swinging the axe handle between his hands.
         "Is fine," said Jill, "perfectly normal." She exchanged a worried look with Jack, who failed to suppress his amused grin.
         The woodsman stepped past Jack and Jill, his rotund belly wobbling as he stepped, and opened the wooden log door. Pausing, he turned back and looked at his visiters. They stood statue-form by a round wooden table that had been piled with opened letters and envelopes. "Could you do something for me?" he asked.
         "Sure," said Jill, nodding.
         "Anything," added Jack, pulling his cape closer around his shoulders.
         The woodsman grinned. "Call me Wally," he said, "'Tis me name. Now then, where to?"
1111.title: Wally the Woodsman

choices: Let Wally rest
Go on without him, he's no help
11111.content:
"Sure thing Wally!" Jack shouted with glee. "Now let's go find the Big Bad Wolf!" Jill noticed Jack's mock enthusiasm and gave him a hard nudge.

"Alright, follow me. After all, I'm very experienced when it comes to wolf catching," Wally said. And with that, the three set off to find the Big Bad Wolf.

However, after about a mile of walking, Wally suddenly stopped. He had been huffing and puffing ever since they left his cabin. "Guys, *whew* lets take a rest," he wheezed.

"Come on Wally, we're not that much farther are we?" Jill said. "Besides, what about Red's poor grandma?"

"I told you this was a mistake!" Jack said.

"Look, I know we aren't far off, but I need the time to rest and plot my next move. They don't call him the Big Bad Wolf for nothing! Catching him and defeating him takes a lot of energy and careful planning. I'm fairly certain we can afford to rest for just a few moments."

Jack and Jill thought for a moment and stared at their rotund, out of breath guide. They decided to...
11111.title: The Journey

choices: It's the Big Bad Wolf!
It's Grandma!
111111.content:
"Fine, you get 5 minutes, and then we'd BETTER find the Big Bad Wolf," Jill said, throwing up her hands in exasperation.

"Thanks, I won't disappoint you!" Wally said. He took a seat on a tree stump and let out a loud sigh. "These dogs sure are barking." He pointed to his feet and took off his shoes. "Whew!"

Jack walked up to Jill. "Do we really have time for this? I mean seriously, Little Red Riding Hood is missing, grandma is about to be digested, and we're sitting here letting this overweight lumberjack rest. I say we leave him now, and go find BBW on our own."

"Look Jack, I feel the same way you do, but we need Wally. He defeated the wolf once and he can do it again," Jill said.

"HOOOOOWEEEE, smell these boots!" Wally said. He had one of his boots in his hand. "Do those Odor Eaters thingys work?"

"Are you sure he can do it again?" Jack asked.

"He'd better be able to," Jill said. The two detectives scanned the forrest, hoping to catch a sight of the Big Bad Wolf while Wally finished his break.

"Alright Wally, time's up," Jill said pointing to her watch. "Time to find the wolf."

"That was the fastest five minutes ever," Wally pouted. He begrudgingly got up from his stump and walked over to Jack and Jill. "But if we must go, it's this way!" He pointed straight ahead and started walking. Suddenly, from the direction he pointed, something came out from behind the trees.

"Uh oh," Jack said.
111111.title: Wally's Break

choices: "Yes"
"No"
1111112.content:
The three looked towards the movement in the brush and were astonished at the sight they saw: an old lady! It was grandma!

"Wow, is that you grandma?" Jack asked.

"Who wants to know?" the old lady asked.

"Only the man who saved your life once upon a time!" Wally said jovially as he walked up to the old lady. "Grandma it's been way too long" He stuck his arms out and tried to engulf her in a bear hug. She responded by slugging him in the shoulder.

"Get away from you fat thing!" the old lady wailed.

"Whoa!" Jill said. "Take it easy here, we're your friends!"

"Yeah, we're just looking for Little Red Riding Hood's grandma," Jack said.

The old lady stared at the three for a moment, then answered, "Who's we?"

"We're your friends," Wally said massaging his shoulder. "Last I checked, friends don't hit friends."

"Easy tiger," Jill said. "I'm Jill and this is my partner Jack. Red's gone missing, and we're on the case. This guy here is Wally. You might recognize him from when he saved you from the Big Bad Wolf."

"Wally? Is that you? Wow you've gotten fat," the old lady said. "I didn't even recognize you!"

"Hey now, take it easy," Wally said, his feelings obviously hurt. "I might look a little round, but it's all muscle!"

"Alright, alright," Jack said, trying to stear the conversation back towards Red. "You're obviously Little Red Riding Hood's grandma. Have you seen her at all today?"

111112.content:
"You're right, Jack," Jill conceded. "Let's just go on without Wall-ee here; I don't think he's in any shape to defeat Big Bad anyway."

They walked aimlessly though the woods, crunching leaves and considering their options when Jack stopped at a fork in the path. He looked down each as far as he could and fidgeted. "You know, Jill, what's the big deal with the grandmother anyway. Do we have any proof that the wolf has eaten her yet?"

"Well, no..."

"So we chose Little Red on a faulty premise. We chose to look for her first since we didn't want to have to investigate a partially digested Grandmother. Makes perfect sense aesthetically, but I think we got sidetracked by the Wally, the formally chiseled woodsman."

"You're right!" gasped Jill. "The real issue is that long list of missing characters. The stories could all come unraveled by morning if we don't locate the kidnapper."

"I was looking down these roads earlier. I think that perhaps we might take the one less traveled and search for clues about the whereabouts of Little Red. In fact, we might as well keep our eyes open for Snow White, too. The Woodsman needs to save her life as well."

Jill sighed. "I wish both of them luck. I'm not sure The Woodsman does much saving anymore."

112.content:
So Jill lead Jack through the woods until they finally got to a quaint little cottage.

Jack gulped. He'd never liked BBW. In fact, he'd always been afraid of the jerky wolf.

Jill resolutely walked up to the door, pounded on it, then without waiting for an answer, walked in.

"BBW! You in here?"

"What?" came a scratchy voice from another room.

Jack and Jill walked into the small room. The large bed with a blue comforter would've looked cute, hadn't it been for the ugly granny lying in it. A granny, with a very hairy face.

"BBW, do you have any idea where Red is?" demanded Jill firmly.

"Just BB, if you please." answered the voice. It wasn't as scratcy now, it was actually very deep and strong. He wasn't pretending to be Granny anymore. "I was wondering the same thing! Granny doesn't agree with my stomach." he said, then moaned.

Jack scanned the room. In a corner, shoved between the side table and the wall, something red was poking out.
         "You stole Little Red, didn't you?" Jack inquired of the wolf. The wolf groaned and mumbled. "Out with it Big Bad, or do you want us to bring up your addiction to the little pigs?"
         "Okay! Okay! I'll tell you, but it isn't pretty," the wolf grumbled, "she made me do it."
         "You're going to have to be more specific than just she," Jill interjected.
         "Alright...it was the Wicked Witch of the West," the wolf let out with another groan. He ran into the bathroom.

11211.content:
Jack and Jill entered the bathroom in time to see BB's transformation. BB blurred and seemed to blend into his surroundings. Then with a soft pop, that sounded like a cork leaving a bottle, he refocused and standing before them was Peter Pan. Jack and Jill had never seen such a jaw dropping thing before and their jaws did indeed drop. It took a few minutes for them to collect their thoughts during which Peter Pan grinned at them broadly. Finally Jill broke the silence with a squeaky whisper.
"What are you doing here?" she asked.
"Just completed my mission," said Peter Pan looking very proud of himself.
"What mission?" asked Jack.
"The one for granny," replied Peter Pan.
Jill let out a long sigh. Things were getting a little complicated. "Perhaps we should start from the beginning," she suggested.
"Okay, but can we go into the living room?" said PP.

In the living room PP explained that Granny had been transported to Never, Never Land where she would never get any older and she would never die. "It's all here," he said as he removed a piece of paper from a pocket in his tunic and handed it to Jill.
Jill stared at the official looking document in her hand and frowned. "Things are worse than we suspected," she said.
"But it's all legal," said Peter Pan. "That's Granny's signature at the bottom.
Jack leaned over to have a look. "Yep," he said. "That's her signature all right."
"This is not good," said Jill. "You do realise you are not supposed to be in this story, don't you?" she said looking at PP.
"Hey, a mission is a mission," said PP. "Besides the money was good."
"So what do we do now?" asked Jill turning to Jack.
"Well there is only one thing we can do," replied Jack.

11221222.content: Flashing a wide grin that made the most of his pearly whites, Johnny reached into a pocket sewn crudely to the front of his vest. Jack, fearing the worst, leaped back, fumbling for the pistol hidden inside his coat."WAIT" shrieked Jill, her eyes locked onto Johnny's. "DON'T SHOOT!". Johnny's hand re-emerged, clutching a tiny, pale green capsule. Visibly confused, Jack made to snatch the pill from the bay's hand, but Johnny was too quick for him. Throwing his hand to his mouth, Jill caught a glance of the green blur hurtling down the lad's throat, and then it was gone. Jack shook the boy hard, yelling words he could barely hear. "WHERE ARE THE OTHERS? TELL ME, OR..." Jack stopped, seeing Johnny's lips move. "Queen... " He gurgled, a strange stillness creeping over him as the poison began to take effect. "What, Johnny? It's okay, you can tell me" Jill said, tears in her eyes as she watched the boy she now recognized as the cat-killer Johnny Stout, once a dear friend to her before the brutal murder of the neighborhood tabby."Us" Jack said insistently, asserting his dominance over quiet Jill. "Ask... heart... duel... before the Court..." his eyes back rolled in their sockets as his breathing slowed to a halt. Johnny was dead. "The Court?" Jill wondered, wiping her eyes and nose as if to erase Johnny's death. "Well, at least we've got a lead" Jack grunted, looking round for Mr Wolf, but the sinister beast had gone, taking Red with him. The little pig, over the shock already, lingered a few minutes to give a statement then fled, disappearing into the undergrowth. "Aw, heck" Jack muttered, looker at Red's hood which lay on the ground. "Why did you let him get away?" Jill hung her head, looking sorrowful. "I..." "Don't worry" said Jack harshly."We'll just have to find this Queen, AND her Court, and get some answers that way". Together, they walked out into the sunshine, squinting at the road ahead.

112212222.content: Suddenly, Jack spied a cloud of dust billowing in the distance. Sprinting to the scene, Jack and Jill found themselves caught in the middle of a whirling mass of birds. Flailing about wildly, Jack fought off the flock, who were unnerved by his strange maneuvers., then turned to Jill. "What do you think that..." He stopped in mid-sentence; something was wrong. "JILL? JILL, WHERE ARE YOU?" he bellowed, looking around frantically. Finally he looked up, and there in the tree was the blue-and-yellow, ex-school scarf she'd been wearing, tangled in the tree branches. Where had Jill gone? Peering up into the tree again, he realized what looked like a grin was forming out of thin air, on top of the old scarf. Slowly, an entire face formed, and as he watched in fascination the rest of the creature appeared too. Flashing its teeth in a way entirely different to Johnny's grin, the Cheshire Cat smirked down at Jack, purring loudly. "What happened to Jill" he called up to it, knowing it knew where his partner had gone. "Before the Court, to stand against the Queen Herself, no less" it chuckled, obviously deeply satisfied at the turn of events. "But... but..." Jack stuttered, astounded by this revelation. "But... she's on THIS case, not some trial for an old queen of some distant land!" The cat considered this, kneading the knitted fabric of the scarf thoughtfully. "The Queen of Hearts waits for no man" it intoned, yawning so that its many vicious fangs could be seen. "So says the White Rabbit, and not even the great Jack himself can deny it." "Me?" the detective, Jack, asked, puzzled."The Jack of legend, of flaming towns and swirling blades, who comes upon the turn of the tide. Jack, whom the Queen locked back in the worlds from which He came. And Jill, key to the case, is key to the chest that binds Him unto His enforced slumber. Oh, pathetic human, you have no idea who your precious Jill really is; what she could become!" With that, the cat faded away, leaving the vague imprint of his smirk against the pine needle.
112212222.title: Jill's disappearing act [part 1]: The Cheshire Cat

choices: Jill's disappearing act [part 3]: Captured!
1122122222.content:
As Jack puzzled over the mystery of Jill's disappearance, something rather more sinister was about to begin. In a world much older than Jack's; a world laid over his own, that was invisible and untouchable, darkness gathered. In a palace far from the point corresponding to Jack's location, the Court met, to discuss the fate of the Key. "The previous events are of no consequence" a deep, earthy voice spoke from beneath the owner's cloak. "The girl; the Key, must be retrieved, and prevented from fulfilling her potential. I say we eliminate the threat, and destroy her". Another voice spoke up, similar to the first. "The Queen of Hearts, the Key to the Chest, Jack of Spades and our own Void, are all inexorable" it said slowly, it's eyes burning blue beneath the shielding cloth."So says the Courts of old, and who are we to deny them?" Beside him, seated upon a hard granite throne, a figure sat up. Her crown, wrought from the twisted hearts of men, glinted in the half-light as the Queen of Hearts raised her head. A new voice, as cold and hard as steel, rose up above the murmurings of her Court. "The Key cannot be truly killed by any, mortal or lord. You speak the truth, Lord Cairn. Her, Jack of Spades and I are somewhat indestructible. As for the Void... we are no longer known by that name. As of last Sun-Return, the Great Jester stripped us of the title, since we have not had a Spade on the throne for nigh on a millennium, though I plan to keep it that way. Once again, we are Wonderland". After the moment of silence that followed her words, Lord Cairn spoke again. "The Key, Your Majesty?" The Queen thought for a moment, her sharp features softened by the smoke-laden air surrounding them. Then she spoke, and this time with a voice tinged with boredom: "I have decided. Once captured, we shall hold the Key in Deep Seven, thus keeping her from releasing Jack of Spades. Septus" she nodded to a skeletal figure waiting by her side. "Find the girl, and bring her to me. Orchus" here, she pointed to another hooded form. "Check on my Lord Jack; ensure he still sleeps". With that, she was suddenly gone.

All at once, the usually reserved Court began to chatter. "Deep Seven?" They all wondered, shaking their heads. A barrel-chested warrior spoke up. "The Lord of Spades is kept in Chamber Two down there... supposing the Queen takes the Key down, what if they react? He'd be free..." All present shuddered, remembering their part in confining Jack of Spades. His retribution would be terrible; how could the Queen risk it? The Deep Quarantine Chambers, or DQC, were where enemies of the Ruler that were not to be executed were held. In Deep Four, the Mad Hatter languished along with nine other souls, jailed for causing Her Majesty displeasure.In Deep Seven, however, there were only two chambers. From far back in the mists of time, there had always been the Powers: the Jester, the Queen of Hearts, the Jack of Spades, the Knave of Diamonds and the Knight of Clubs. Each Power had a Key; a person solely dedicated to the restoration of them, for each Key was only born if a Power was denied. Locked in an infinite sleep, the Jack of Spades was in line for a Key. The Queen and the Jester were the ones who ruled, thus not requiring a Key; the Queen held Wonderland, the Jester held Earth, and the other Powers went by different titles and occupations. The Knave of Diamonds was known as the Mad Hatter, and had his estate in the Wild Woods bordering Wonderland, although he was currently under temporary arrest. The Knight of Clubs traveled under the name the White Rabbit, and ruled the Under-lands. And Jack, if freed, would rule them all. Thus He was kept in Deep Seven, the safest place in all Wonderland, and also the best guarded, for the Queen could not afford for Him to escape, for her and the Jester would be banished to the Nether Realms, where all Powers were originally formed.

Deep down in the bowels of the earth, suspended in His slumber, the Lord of Spades dreamed of the boy searching for his lost partner, and smiled in His sleep. Jack Crown, in the Other World, stumbled desolately down a dusty track, facing a new case to solve. He had to find the Court, and get Jill back. After all, he reasoned, good assistants were hard to find.
1122122222.title: Jill's disappearing act [part 2]: The Court

choices: Jill's disappearing act [part 4]: Who's afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?
Jill's disappearing act [part 4]: The White Rabbit
11221222221.content:
Far away from both her partner Jack and the Court, Jill groaned softly as she opened her eyes, having just regained consciousness. Where was she? She could remember a sandstorm, screaming birds, a panicked Jack... and then darkness. She went to rub her blurry eyes, then found her arms were somehow strapped tightly to her sides.
Blinking, Jill felt dizzy as the room swam into view, then wished she hadn't woken up. "Took you long enough" an amused, somewhat ironic female voice said, coming nearer as she felt footsteps come towards her. Cool fingers carefully brushed the remaining dust from her eyes as Alice of Wonderland loomed high above her, her gray-blue eyes triumphant as she surveyed her captive. Struggling against her bonds, Jill tried to sit up, but found she couldn't quite balance, and slipped back to the wooden floor.
"Would you like some help?" Alice asked, and without waiting for a reply grasped Jill's elbows and firmly levered her upright.
"That's better. Sorry about the straitjacket; it's just a precaution, you know? Can't have you attempting to break free, now that I've found you."
Swallowing her confusing, Jill found her voice. "And why am I here?" she asked, looking round for an escape route.
There were none to be seen. Alice took her time answering, pacing up and down the underground room as she thought up a reply.
"Well, you are the last Key, you know. No more can ever be born; for once the sleeping Lord is wakened He'll never sleep again". Thoroughly confounded, Jill remained silent, and after a moment Alice continued:
"I was the White Rabbit's Key, on that first venture into Wonderland. I was from Earth, like you, until they claimed me as his Key, but now I'm a retired Power since I fulfilled my duty. But, now that I've found you, I can't let you fulfill yours." J
ill looked at Alice questioningly, her eyes troubled, and Alice went on: "I'm a little sorry about this, but I can't let you free Jack of Spades. He'll absorb the White Rabbit's territory into His own, and since the White Rabbit gave me a patch to myself He will take that too. So you're trapped down here for good, since you can't really die, and anyway I'd not want to kill you, since in a way I think you're like me. Better get used to this room, kid. It's your world now".
Having explained, Alice left Jill to her own devices, and Jill realized that Alice had meant it. but on the bright side, she reasoned, she'd found Missing 'Hero' No. 21. If only Jack knew... suddenly she wondered what had happened to Jack. "I hope he's okay!" she muttered under her breath, then turned to the pressing question of Keys. What was a Key? What was a 'Jack of Spades'? Was it her Detective Jack? Why was Alice behaving weirdly? Jill slowly forced herself onto her feet, and started towards where Alice had gone, intending to get answers.
11221222221.title: Jill's disappearing act [part 3]: Captured!

choices: Jill's disappearing act [part 4]: Jack's Dream
112212222211.content:
Even further away from both Jack, the Court and Jill, a strange creature travelled through the forest, sprinting on all fours towards a towering cliff face. Slowing as it neared the rock, the beast looked around quickly before darting into a well-concealed cave.
Tied to the creature's back was a screaming, howling red bundle. Standing up on it's hind legs, it swung its writhing burden onto the floor, and busied itself making its dinner. "WOLF!" the little bundle screamed, managing to free one if its limbs. "UNTIE ME AT ONCE, YOU FIEND!"
The Wolf yawned, picked at his teeth a little, and went back to his cooking. In a small pot, he stirred a meaty broth, regretting stealing the hysterical little girl. Who happened to be a practising member of one of the largest karate clubs in Wonderland, hence the bruises he could feel as he stirred his pot.
"Shut the hell up, Red!" he snarled at the flailing bundle, waving his wooden spoon threateningly at her.
She looked at the large collection of nunchucks, star blades, and daggers arraying the western wall of his cave. She wriggled round to stare at the painting of death on the wall. Then she laughed.
Mr Wolf felt exasperated. How was he supposed to be scary when everyone laughed at him? Was it his beautiful honey-coloured eyes, his mother's pride and joy? Was it the small bald patch on the top of his head, from where he'd scalded it on the Three Little Pig's caudron of soup? Or was it the way his partner in the back of the cave snored? What ever it was, he was sick of it. What was the point of being a wolf if he wasn't frightening?
Having already sufficiently frightened Red the last time she visited dear old Granny, he'd thought it would be a piece of cake, scaring her again. Thought admittedly, he thought, that was seven years ago and Red had grown up since then, being now 18, a karate champion and a mean cupcake-baker to boot.
Turning back to Red, who was still laughing uncontrollably, he decided to take action. She was firmly bound he reasoned, and unable to beat the living daylights out of him, so he went for revenge. Hovering over her for a moment, he choose to boot her very, very hard in the stomach.
That would show the swine. However, what he hadn't done was take into account her awesome karate skills, and more importantly, her flailing arm. Waiting until Mr Wolf was just about to kick her, Red struck.
Suddenly, Wolf felt a blinding pain erupt from his groin. "AHHHHHHHHHHH!" he yelled, scrabbling back from the girl as fast as she could, tears filling his eyes. From the back of the cave came a drawn-out yawn, and his partner emerged, rubbing the sleep from his eyes. "Wolfy, what's wrong?" he asked, extending a paw to pull Mr Wolf upright.
"Little brat punched me in the nuts!" Wolf coughed, his legs tightly crossed.
Red saw Wolf's partner, and began to cackle again. "GAY!" she shrieked, rolling on the cave floor in mirth. "Ha; I knew it!"
Going as red as was possible for a wolf, Mr Wolf blushed. "Red, I'd like you to meet Alfred" he said, pointing to the grey wolf beside him. Turning to Alfred, he pointed to the laughing girl and introduced Red to him. "Alfred, this is Red, formerly known as Little Red Riding Hood, four times Karate Kid of the Year, recently awarded Guides Wonderland, who is a senior Ranger, and also a leading junior reporter".
Alfred whistled, clearly impressed. "You forgot one" said Red, untying herself with her free arm. "Cousin to Alice of Wonderland". "Yes, yes" interrupted Alfred. "But where are we to keep our guest?"
Now freed of her bonds, Red stood up. "Awww; isn't that cute! Wolfy found a friend!" she said, looking Alfred up and down. "Oh, come on, Wolfy. We shall simply have to let her go" Alfred looked over at Mr Wolf. "She'll come between us; the togetherness we have. Off you go, little girl".
Agreeing somewhat with his mate, Mr Wolf led Red to the cave entrance to let her go. "But don't you dare tell" he growled, once out of earshot from Alfred. "We have a nice lifestyle, peaceful, like, and I'll not have you ruining it". He looked menacingly at Red, willing her to agree.
"Sure thing, Wolfy" Red sang airily, pleased to have met a real live all-male marrige. "But don't harrass my Granny ever again". Conceeding to this, he went back into his cave, shaking his shaggy head, and Red went on her way.
112212222211.title: Jill's disappearing act [part 4]: Mr Wolf

choices: Who am I? Part One: I Beg to Differ
1122122222111.content:
Asleep in His cell in Deep Seven, Jack of Spades dreamed. Vague visions of fire, sharply contrasted against darkness, filled His mind as His sub-conscious dwelt on His past lives. The world burnt again, the sounds of screaming villagers rising in His ears like it did so long ago. But who had begun the chaos? It was this point that He dwelt on always, trapped as He was in the long hours of sleep.
A blurred face, streaked with blood and dirt... the dull thump of an exploding cannon, the shrill keening of a weeping winner. But who had won the war? Why the bitter sorrow, painted across the conquerer of the worlds in blue and grey?
Unable to truly awake, Jack of Spades found Himself thinking. At last! he thought, then wondered, why? There was a change in the pattern, He decided. A rift; a frayed thread in the fabric of reality. All of Wonderland had descended from those who survived the war, and it was they who wove the pattern now. Not mighty sorcerers, twisting the strands of the weave until they distorted and warped, but the remaining creatures; those who had become the so-called 'fairy tale heroes'. So what was wrong with them? It seemed to Jack that there was almost something missing, like a whole lifetime of memories had been found to have been misplaced or lost. Indeed, that WAS reality; He couldn't even remember why He was here, where ever here was. Or who He was... suddenly a strange thought entered His mind: was He a he? 'Jack' implied a certain male element, but He doubted He could go by that alone... but He just had to escape this dreamstate. Unknown to Him though, help was on its way.
1122122222111.title: Jill's disappearing act [part 4]: Jack's Dream

choices: Who am I? Part Two: Strike Three, and You're Out
Who am I? Part Two: The Powers and Poisons of Thought
11221222221111.content:
The aforementioned help, however, had found itself in quite some trouble. Finding her attempts to free herself from the straitjacket fruitless, Jill cautiously followed after Alice, thinking very rude and vengeful thoughts against her red-haired captor. The sound of running water could be heard, masking both her and Alice's footsteps, and soon she was lost in the maze of tunnels that linked the chambers in Alice's domain. "Oh yes, Jill, VERY well done" she muttered to herself sarcastically, trying to keep track of the twists and turns in case she needed to backtrack pronto. The air became colder, and soon she realized that the scanty light from candles set into the walls was fading as she passed the last of them. Was she reaching the surface, or going deeper in? Feeling particularly negative because of her current captivity, Jill decided on the latter. Treading lightly on the slightly soft soil, straining her ears for any sound, Jill was so intent on being silent and listening for others that she didn't realize Alice was ahead, and watching her, til she found herself reeling back after bowling Alice over. "Oi!" Alice snarled, trying to regain her footing. "Sorry; got to go" Jill said, and wished she'd said something a bit more intelligent, just as a parting shot. Then she was off, up towards the glorious light that proved her wrong, leaving Alice in her wake. Exulting in her escape, Jill stumbled across the dew-laden grass of the outer world, pleased with her small success, planning what to do next. But her new-found freedom didn't seem so certain, when after a sweet moment of brief peace, Alice came hurtling out of the tunnel.

Turning to face her, Jill glared defiance at the other girl, annoyed at the impending imprisonment that threatened to put an end to her endeavors. "Now, you'll come along quietly, yes? Like before" Alice asked, her teeth bared in a feral grin as she watched Jill eye her warily. "Oh, but this time I beg to differ" Jill tartly replied, then stared in amazement at the change her words had inspired in Alice. What began as a silent heaving of the shoulders erupted into a full-hearted chuckle as Alice laughed. "You are still straitjacketed, don't know where you are, have a price on your head and you're trying to escape? Oh, but that's just too ironic for words". Jill stopped her glaring momentarily to consider this strange revelation. A price on her head? As unfortunate as it was, she decided she'd have to postpone her escape long enough to hear the explanation owing on the topic. "Do explain" she said with as much venom she could muster, then settled on the damp grass to hear the reply. Her hands up in front of her in a gesture of peace, Alice came and sat down beside her. "In short, the Queen in her infinite wisdom has placed a bounty on your head. 'Dead or Alive' I believe she stated, although you technically can't be killed unless you are back in your own world, where ever that may be."
"Dead or alive? That's just a little bit OTT, don't you think?" Jill sighed sadly, wondering what the world was coming to. "Maybe, but I don't think she minds if whoever catches you tries to kill you, since she's fond of torture. Finds it quite enjoyable, or so I'm told. Point is, don't you think you'd be safer locked away in a cell somewhere in my turf, rather than being hunted and chased all over Wonderland?" Jill pondered this for a bit, turning the fresh scenario over in her mind, trying to find an angle that suited her best.
"I don't have too much of a choice in this, do I?" She asked, knowing what the answer would be. Confirming her suspicions, Alice nodded, and stood ready to escort Jill back to her new home. 'THAT was pointless then' Jill thought glumly, wondering what to do now. The future seemed so bleak, what with the whole 'kept like Alice's pet' thing, and all. Sighing deeply, her thoughts turned to Jack.
11221222221111.title: Who am I? Part One: I Beg to Differ

113.content:
'Okay. Shall we go to the last place she was seen?'

Jack followed her to the woods, though reluctantly. His ears were still red after hearing her previous remark. Now that he thought about it, his question really, really sounded dumb. Of course! How could he forget that the Granny was in the middle of being digested? That was really embarrassing. He was the Sherlock, wasn't he? He shouldn't forget such important fact like that, let alone being lectured by the Watson. If his friends heard, his reputation as the smart guy would have ruined in a blink of an eye.

But he tried to hide those wicked thoughts in the back of his mind. Someone's life was in trouble here, and it wasn't the time to complain about who should be smarter here. He could still prove her that he was much smarter.

Jill suddenly stopped. 'Okay. Red's mother last saw her when she went to this wood with some breads and wine for the Grandma. Perhaps, if we can find other witnesses, we can locate where that girl is.'

'Sounds great, sounds great,' he said. 'Except one thing: who should we talk to? We're in the middle of the forest! There's nobody here. How big is the chance there might be any witness she ever came here?'

Well, at least it was her turn to make a dumb question. She wouldn't act so haughtily anymore.

But Jill just stared at him for a moment. 'There's still ....................,' she said. 'Duh.'

1133.content:
"Isn't the Old Oak supposed to be dead?", Jack asked, slightly irritated. "I thought I remembered something about a last dream and a storm at Christmas..."
"You silly!", Jill sighed. "Do I have to tell you the ground rules of fairy tales all over again? Did you pay any attention in Detective School or not? Nobody really dies here, as long as the fairy tales go as planned. They just rewind and start all over again!"
"Oh...right!" Jack couldn't think of any wittier remark to make.

When they reached the Old Oak, that stood on a little hill at the outskirts of the forest, it was fast asleep.
Jack cleared his throat. "Mr. Oak! I'm Detective Crown, this is my colleague Jill Pail. We are investigating in the case of a missing 7 year old and would like to ask you a few questions."
The oak tree rustled its leaves. "What? Where? Who? I was just in the middle of the best dream ever! Why did you wake me up?", it exclaimed.
Jill took over: "Have you seen a little girl around here? When she was last seen, she was wearing a red riding hood."
"I haven't seen anyone, I was sleeping. Until you woke me up!", said the oak, staring reproachful at Jack.
"Well, thanks for your help anyway!", said Jill and drew Jack away.

"What now?", she asked as soon as they were out of earshot.
"The oak doesn't have an alibi!", Jack thought loudly.
"Yes, but it can't move either. Where should it have hidden the girl?" Jill rolled her eyes.
"Good point!", Jack answered, making sure to have the last word. "Let's ..."

“The Pied Piper,” announced Jill.

“Hmm. You may have a point,” he conceded, reluctantly. “It’s just… well… the Pied Piper has always given me the creeps. The pale skin, the colourless eyes, that horrible patchwork costume of his – I just hoped for an easier first job, that’s all.”

“We need to think about the elements of the Pied Piper’s previous career,” Jack said authoritatively. “What do we know about his back-story?”

Jill considered this question for a minute. “We know he has a love of money. And that he can hold a grudge. Oh, that he carries out most his work in Germany.”

“Now we are getting somewhere,” Jack chipped in. “Wasn’t there a little lame boy that figured?”

“Yes. Hans Galler. He is now grown up, and he’s lonely. There is no-one in his village of his age. He might hold the key.”

“What are we waiting for? Bring him in for questioning,” ordered Jack. Jill didn’t like this new found bossiness Jack was beginning to display.

“Jack, he is in Germany. And why would other characters go missing?”

“You can never tell with these loner sorts. He has probably spent a lifetime of resentment at not being included. And what are fairy tales about if not inclusion? Extradite him now.”

1232.content:
"Come in, come in." The witch motioned to Jack and Jill, holding the door open to her wooden cottage. "I have been expecting you."

Jill looked at Jack and shrugged. "We have come here for help in..."

"In finding The Piper." The witch blurted in.

"Yes." Jill pulled out her small notebook from her shirt pocket and flipped it open.

"Have a seat. I was just finishing up some hot tea." The witch pointed to the table. Jack pulled out his chair and motioned for Jill to do the same.

"Jill and I were wondering if you by chance..."

"Had a pipe?" The witch turned to the table with the teapot in hand and a smile on her face.

"Uh, yes." Jack paused out of bewilderment. He watched as the witch slowly poured the hot tea into the three cups that were positioned directly in front of them.

"What we really want to know," Jill began, "is if we could..."

"Have the pipe to be able to find The Piper." The witch nudged the cup of steaming tea toward Jill.

"Okay, you really have to stop that. Can you help us, or not?" Jill slapped her notebook onto the table. The witch pulled her chair from the table and joined the two detectives.

"Why of course I can, darlings. First, why don't you drink this delicious tea that I have made? Your mouths must be awfully dry from the travel."

12321.content:
Without even thinking, Jack and Jill sipped their tea with gusto. The witch leaned closered and smiled, her horrible, rotting teeth even more viewable.

"Thats it... Go on, drink some more..."

By the time Jack realized that something about this situation just wasn't right, he was already slipping into a stupor. The last thing he saw before going unconscious was the witch's ugly face leaning over him, her great worty nose obscuring almost all of his vision.

"Thought I might get the bounty on you fairy tale types. Didn't think I'd notice you had your own story once? I see everything you fools!"

And with that, she let out her resounding evil cackle, the ever so annoying type. Jack would have been glad he was unconscious.

*******

Jack awoke slowly, feeling hard manacles around his wrists and a hard, cold floor beneath his feet. Apparently he was chained to a wall. Groggily, he opened his eyes and willed himself to see. Slowly, the details of his predicament came into view. He was in a small, dirty tower with small bits of disgusting cloth and straw littering the floor. Rats scurried to and fro, oblivious to the what they were wallowing in, squeaking out information to their brethren.

Finally, his vision cleared completely and he was able to make out the blurry form chained across the room from him.

"Jill! What happened? Where are we?"

No answer. Apparently she was still knocked out from the witch's unholy brew. In frustration, he rattled his chains and angrily sighed. It looked like they were stuck here...

Then Jack noticed the effect his shaking had on the chains. They were a great deal looser. He looked up, to where they were planted in the wall and noticed the old, crumbling stone around the emplacements. It didn't look very stable and he was sure with a few good shakes, they would come right off...

Jack shook the chains again, pulling and tuggging frantically until the old stone crumbled and he was free. He jumped up and rushed to Jill's aid. After unbounding her, he shook her awake. "What's going on?" she asked, still blinking away the unconsciousness.

Jack pulled her to her feet. "The witch poisoned and kidnapped us!" he announced.

"SHE's the one that's been abducting the other characters!" Jill concluded.

"Exactly! But we've escaped! Now, let's find a way out of here so we can report the witch to the authorities."

Jack broke down the old, wooden door and led Jill down the long, dark halls until they found their freedom. Only once outside, they didn't know where to go.

"Let's just go straight through the woods until we come off on the other side," Jill suggested. So they walked through the woods for what seemed like hours before finally reaching the town on the other side.

They headed straight to the Fairytale Land Police Station to report what they've learned. After informing the police of the witch's evil deeds, the sheriff shook his head.

"I'm sorry kids, but it wasn't the witch who kidnapped you. Or at least, she isn't the once who kidnapped the other characters."

Bewildered, Jill cried, "How do you know?"

"Because," the sherriff replied. "The mirror on the wall was just in here this morning to report that the witch, herself, has been abducted!"

"The witch?" Jack demanded. "But-"

"She's a fairytale character, too, afterall," the Sheriff pointed out.

Now more confused than ever, Jack turned to Jill and asked, "Now what?"

choices: "The Muffin Man! Come on, what kind of question is that?!"

132112.content:
"Does Peter know how Tinkerbell reacted when she arrived?" Jill asked cautiously. When Jack gave her a look (which she could sum up in a four-letter word), she spurted, "I'm so sorry, but we need to know. For the investigation."

Her Majesty seemed peeved, but nodded to concede. "We did not give him the full details, but he seemed cognizant of her anger. Seems she tried to have an innocent girl shot down by pirates and even Peter's own Lost Boys." A thought seemed to have occurred to her and she lost a bit of her anger. "They will probably have seen him last."

"When did you see him last?" Jack asked.

"A few months ago. The poor boy looked frazzled. He has that job, you know, escorting the souls of murdered children on their way to the next world, and it seemed to be taking a toll on him."

"Escorting the souls of murdered children?" Jill asked, more to herself than anyone else.

"It's not that he minds. He's got a good heart, that boy. He wants children to be lost on their terms, not someone elses. Does that make any sense?"

"Well, considering the source, yes." Jack said. "Did he say anything specific?"

"No. He'd just had a few rough nights that week. Or so he said. My Court Magician thinks he was suffering from dehydration and insomnia due to the side effects of a type of Lover's Draft."

"A love potion?" Jill asked, again more to herself.

"Well, why else would he let that little so-and-so stick around so long?" The Queen snapped.

"Thank you, Your Majesty." Jack bowed and flashed her his best grin. "We are greatly in debted to you."

Jill bowed. "Yes, thank you very much."

They gathered the dust into a silk bag the Queen's courtesean brought them and left the garden.

"A love potion?" Jill said. "What do you think of that?"

"I think she's been drugging him to get him to stay with her."

"But she can't possibly hope to have a relationship with a prepubescent boy!"

Jack stopped on the street and gave her a hard look. "Yeah. A fairy is slipping a human love potions and age is the problem? You are a strange individual."

Jill scoffed. "Okay, for one thing, who said Pan was even human? And for another, if she's slipping him love potions, what else would she be after?"

"Well, she'd be crazy to attempt a romantic relationship," Jack began. They continued walking back to their office. "And she surely knows that. So she's probably tweaking the potion. Lover's Draft isn't a potion for true love, it's for infatuation. It wouldn't be that hard, especially for a someone who specializes in brewery and herbs, to tweak the potion so that it will cause an intense longing for the brewer's presence, but with no romance in it at all."

Jill considered this for a moment. "What do we know about Tinkerbell?"

They headed to the police station on Drury Lane. At this hour, just before dusk, the street didn't have much traffic. The usual steady flow in and out of the Muffin Man's shop was about all. They took the back door into the basement and drudged around for Tinkerbell's file.

"Here it is!" Jack pulled out a bright purple folder with yellow glitter. "Let's see. Birthname: Amalthea Tinkerbell of Dragon's Wort, full title: the Right and Honorable Lady Amalthea Tinkerbell Tarragon, Duchess Tarragon Second-Descending. Father is the Honorable Bromios Redthumb, the Duke of Tarragon, Mayor of Dragon's Wort. Mother is Her Highness Sarah Merriweather, Duchess of Chives in Puzzlewood."

"Fancy bloodlines she's got, there."

"Says here she was sent to a nunnery for fighting with the girls at her grammar school. After she left, she fell in with the court of the Fairydom of Never-Never and took to the boy who became the new Pan."

"Anything else?"

"A few citations for disturbing the peace, one assault and battery with a frilly weapon...oh!"

"What?"

"It says here that the King of Never-Never indicted her on two counts attempted girlslaughter."

"Is that even an applicable legal term?"

"It is in Never-Never. The report says that she attempted to have a certain Wendy Darling of Kensington shot down, first by the crew of the Jolly Roger, and again the same day by the Lost Boys!"

"The Queen mentioned that."

Jack closed the file. "Let's go upstairs and get some supplies for the trip."

At the top of the stairs, they met Detective Heart.

"Hey Knavey! What's going on?" Jill asked.

"I'm coming down to get Puss' boots out of evidence."

"Have you got any leads on him?" Jack asked.

"Oh, we found him already. Turns out it's hard to tell one cat from another when the only distinguishing characteristic is the boots, which we had, so when he came to report them stolen, it was pretty easy to find him." He spun on his heels once and proceeded down the steps. They watched him go and when he got to the floor and was out of sight, Jack muttered, "The transfers from Wonderland are always so spaced out..."

"So for food, should we go to the Muffin Man or grab whatever's in the lounge?" Jill asked.

133.content:
Jill smiled wryly. “I’ve got a silver dollar. Maybe we should start with the wishing well? It’s closer than anywhere else but the bottom of the garden – and I for one don’t want to have to shake any fairies down for their dust. They can give a nasty nip!”

“Right. The wishing well,” agreed Jack, just relieved that Jill hadn’t been too scathing about his plan.

They set out toward the centre of town, lilac cobbles paving their way. If the Well-genie was in a good mood, they could have the fairy-dust in a matter of minutes. Of course, it all depended on how much djinn-juice he’d been drinking the night before. They’d just have to hope they got lucky, that was all.

When they got there, however, it became obvious that something bigger than the search for fairy-dust was going on here. A crowd of onlookers were trying to out-shout each other and there was something in the centre of the circle, beside the well itself.

Jack wasted no time, pushing through the crowd… and Jill was right behind him. Thus, her nose hit him in the small of the back as he came to a sudden halt.

“Ow!” she said, in a slightly nasal voice. Then she saw what he was looking at and her eyes widened.

In the centre of the circle stood two… things! Loosely speaking, Jill supposed they were human-ish, but no human she’d ever seen had green warty skin, bulbous eyes and a bright-red inflatable throat and chest. They looked like the human equivalent of toads, or…

She groaned. “Frogs. Don’t tell me – the Frog Prince is missing too!”

“You bet he’s gone missing!” croaked one of the huma-frogs. “Three days and he hasn’t been back once to see how his poor old mother’s doing. Leaves me to take care of the well without so much as a ‘by your leave!’ Who’s going to scrape up the well scum – that’s what I want to know!”

“What happened?” asked Jack, helplessly.

The frog-thing glared at him, then shrugged and answered.

“Well, I was out at the edge of the well, looking to see where my son had got to… lousy good-for-nothing toad that he is… and the next thing you know, some passing Princess with gender blindness has picked me up and planted a smacker on my lips. Then, she turns into that – and I turn into this – and now I can’t get back into my well and she’s talking law-suits and treason charges. As if it was my fault she sexually assaulted me. Pah!”

Jill looked at the creature sympathetically. “Oh, you poor thing! Jack – we can’t just leave them like this – we’ve got to do something!”

Jack winced. Where animals were concerned, Jill was often far too sympathetic for her own good. “I thought we were supposed to be tracking down Peter Pan?” he said, helplessly.

“AND setting the other fairy-tales back on their track,” reminded Jill, bristling slightly.

“All right,” sighed Jack. “Here’s what I suggest.”

1331221212.content:
"We can't just keep backing and forthing all day!" protested Jack. "Have you SEEN the list of missing fairy-tale characters? It's huge - and we haven't even got as far as the first on the list yet! Jill - be reasonable, let's just..."

He trailed off helplessly, noting that Jill had already disappeared back into the witch's cottage. Muttering under his breath he hurried to follow her in.

"You again?" snarled the witch. "What do you want this time?"

Jill smiled airily. "Nothing much. I just thought you might have reconsidered, that's all."

"Reconsidered?" The witch threw her ugly head back and cackled insanely. "And why in fairyland would I want to reconsider? I've just got myself a very useful drudge, thanks to you two. And if you're not careful, I'll have myself two more!"

Jill fixed her with a patronising look.

"You really don't know what you're dealing with here, do you?" she said, sympathetically.

"Huh? What are you talking about?"

"Look," said Jill, sitting down in the witch's armchair, "We have fairy tale characters going missing all over the land. Right? And we have fairy tales aching to be completed - only there's nobody around to complete them. Do you know anything about causality rifts?"

"Caus-whattity?" snarled the witch.

"Causality," sighed Jill. "It's a type of magic. I'll try to explain. You see, if Snow White goes missing, then some other girl with hair as black as ebony, skin as white as snow and lips as red as rubies is going to find herself hunted down by a wicked stepmother. It won't matter if it's not REALLY Snow White. By the time the story's done with her, she might as well be."

The witch glared at her. "What's that got to do with anything? What's it got to do with me?"

"You've only gone and started off another fairy-tale, right here in your own cottage!" Jill shook her head, reproachfully. "Couldn't be plainer! You've taken a princess and turned her into a servant, ruled by someone evil and rather... well... nasty. You just KNOW how that's got to turn out. And then, to add insult to injury, you want to use the power of three? Turn three of us into ugly servants and you can't help but find yourself in an oven by the time the story ends. It's all perfectly logical, when you think about it."

For the first time, the witch looked uncertain.

"That sort of thing doesn't really happen!" she snapped. Then: "Does it?"

Jill turned to Jack who was standing gaping at her in disbelief. "Jack - tell her," she ordered.

Jack hesitated, torn between rescuing the princess and putting Jill in her place once and for all. He opened his mouth...

choices: ...that princess is magically bound to my house! She can't leave! Ha!

13312212121.content:
...and found himself insisting loudly, "Oh, it happens quite often!" Then, struck by sudden and brilliant inspiration, Jack drew the Witch of the West close to him, leaning his head toward hers conspiratorially and lowering his voice to what was still a rather theatrical whisper. "As a matter of fact, my good friend--well I rather think I should leave names out of it--"

"Oh, but I won't tell a soul!" the Witch of West swore earnestly, clinging to his arm and trying to look as trust-worthy as possible by pouting out her bottom lip as far as it would go and blinking her forcibly widened eyes as quickly and as often as she could.

Jack shook his head and said with just the right amount of hesitancy in his voice, "I'm sorry, but there really is such a thing a client confidentiality, and I can't--"

"Please?" The witch's pout, which Jack suspected had been magically enhanced, now reached past her chin, and her eyelashes were in such a flurry Jack was surprised the witch could see past them at all.

"Oh, all right, I'll tell you her nickname," Jack conceded with a dramatic sigh. "Everyone back in high school used to call her the 'Queen of Hearts' and--by the way, have you ever tried her tarts?"

The witch shook her head.

"Oh, they're just delicious!" From there, Jack allowed his mouth to take over while he focused all of his energies on leading the all-too-eager Wicked Witch of West away from Jill and the erst-while princess.

"--and then there was this Knave of Hearts, well, you can just imagine what kind of guy HE is. Anyway, he stole the tarts--" Barely aware of the words that were spilling out of his mouth, Jack motioned furiously behind his back for Jill to grab the princess and get out. The witch was too engrossed in the gossip to notice the slight shuffling as Jill gathered up the princess and moved toward the exit, but Jack had to work cover up the princess's indignant cry of, "Hey! Get your own toothbrush!"

"AND THEN HE BEAT THE KNAVE FULL SORE! HA! ISN'T THAT A GOOD STORY?" Jack practically screamed the words in the witch's ear. Thankfully, the witch started cackling, which covered up the sound of boot meeting flesh. Jack risked a quick look backward and saw Jill rubbing her shin as the princess redoubled her mad efforts to clean the floor with her newly reclaimed toothbrush. Jill was on the princess in a second and started wrestling her to the door.

Jack turned back to the witch, whose eyes were tearing, and added his own too-loud laughter to her high-pitched shrieks of mirth.

"Oh, that was a good one!" said the Witch of the West, wiping a tear from her eye. "Do you want to hear another good one?"

Jack nodded and said a shade too brightly, "Why yes, of course!"

"Well, you see..."

“You’ve no idea how long I’ve waited to do that!” the Princess exclaimed.

“Princess Ada.”
“Princess Ada!” Jill suddenly gasped.

“Our list?”

The Princess took this moment to explain her situation.
“I was out in the garden, tending the pea plants when I was set upon by this horrid woman. She claimed to be an old woman, lost in the woods. I said that I would help her by accompanying her to the other side. Once we’d passed Priest’s Clearing she wandered off the path, worried, I followed her and it was there she cast her wicked spell. She transformed me into a frog and said that the only way I was allowed to turn back was if I kissed another frog. Trust me to pick one that would lead me straight back to her.”

14.content: Jack Crown and Jill Pail set off down the country lanes in search of the home of Jack, the boy of Beanstalk fame. They questioned the cow, who ended up being set to pasture in a neighbouring town. The cow, in predictable fairytale fashion gave our intrepid detectives directions to the house. Although as you came close you would have known the very house without looking for it. The infamous beanstalk covered all the fields as it lay rotting after being cut down. At the front door of a quaint country cottage with ivy circling the door they knocked and waited. Eventually a decidedly upset mother came to the door. "You've come about my son!" she cried and let them into the house. Keeping herself busy making tea and crumpets for Jack and Jill she explained how her beloved son had vanished shortly after slaying the giant above the clouds. "He just didn't come home after going to market a second time. Without our cow we were without milk." she explained in a tearful voice. Jack made notes while Jill made sympathetic noises to try and keep Jack's mother calm. It was peculiar how he had simply vanished into thin air. They thanked Jack's mother for her time and left. There next destination...
14.title: The search for Jack's house...

141.content:
There next destination was the office where they could talk privately without interruptions from fairy tale creatures who liked to talk.

"I don't have a good feeling about this," said Detective Crown to his partner, Pail. "This is Jack's second disappearance, only this time, there don't seem to be any beanstalks leading up to the clouds. Unless..."

"Unless what?" Jill demanded. "I hate it when you do this to me. Know I suppose you are going to say, 'Forget it, Pail. It was just a passing thought.'"

"Forget it, Pail. It was... Hey! How'd you know I was going to say that?" Jack Crown was incredulous. "What are you, anyway... a psycho?" He grinned, then laughed too loudly over his own words.

"Psychic, pscho-yourself. It's called being psychic. And no, you weren't funny in the least. You always tell me to forget it whenever there's a pause after the word Unless. Jill kicked off her spike heals. "My feet are killing me." She began rubbing them.

"Hey, what's that stuck to the bottom of your shoe?" Jack asked, leaning forward for a better view. "That's a dang bean! Do you think..."

Jill slipped her shoes back on after peeling the bean off the soul of her shoe. "Let's experiment. I'll carry this up the hill while you pull up water from the well with the bucket. Let's see if this thing will grow."

"Hold on a minute!" the detective barked. "Last time I went up that hill, I came tumbling down and broke my crown. I don't every want to do that again!"

"Grow up, Jack. We're professionals now, not kids. If you're going anywhere, it will be up a beanstalk and if you don't hold on tight, you'll be tumbling down a beanstalk and breaking more than your crown. Now let's go!"

Twenty minutes later, Jack was huffing and puffing on top of the hill. "Man, I'm outta shape," he said, wiping sweat from his forehead. The protective motorcycle helmet he wore was heavy and hot.

Jill, however, ignored him and dug a hole in the ground about ten feet from the well. "We're ready for the water," she announced impatiently.

Jack managed to carry the bucket over to Jill without falling down the hill. He poured water over the planted spot until Jill told him to stop. It was almost immediate when the bean sprouted and then shot upward through the air!

"Come on!" Jill called out, already six feet up the thick, green trunk of the beanstalk. "Hurry, slowpoke!"

He would have a talk with her when this was all done and over with. Her disrespect towards him was wearing thin. He was a detective now, not an ungraceful fairy tale character.

At last, they reached the top. And there, as imagined, was the giant's house in the clouds.

[472 words]
141.title: The giants house in the clouds...

1413.content:
The castle was huge, which of course made sense since it was built for giants. But where are they, Jill wondered. She definitely wasn't in any hurry to meet up with any mean giants. Hopefully, Crown and her could find Jack Bean and bring him home quickly.

"You can take that helmet off now," Jill said. "Just remember to put it back on once we head back down... just in case."

"You don't need to remind me," said Jack. "I'm gonna leave it right here, next to the beanstalk."

"Good idea," said Jill. "Now... Where should we begin? The castle?"

"Sure. I wouldn't recommend calling out Bean's name though. We'll want to avoid giants at all cost."

"I agree, "said Jill. "Hey, what's that up ahead?"

"Looks like Jack Bean to me," said Detective Crown. "He's... ugh... whistling. And... skipping? Huh. He looks pretty happy. I find that weird."

"Let's go talk to him," Jill suggested.

Jack Bean jumped when he spotted the two detectives. "Sorry," he apologized. "I haven't seen any normal sized people since I got here. It's strange."

"Where are the giants?" asked Jill, glancing around.

"Gone," said Bean. "When I came back the second time around, there was a note nailed to the door. It said: Vacant. Available for Free. Tenants have permanently vacated."

"Good to know," said Crown.

"I'm having the time of my life," said Bean. "I never want to go back down the beanstalk."

"Your mother is worried about, Jack," said Pain. "You should go for a visit."

"Or bring her back up here," said Crown. "She is family, you realize."

"I know, I know..." Bean kicked a few loose stone around with his big toe." It's just..." He examined the dirt under his nails. "I have my garden to keep and baby geese to feed and... I should dust. You wouldn't believe how dusty it gets up here in the clouds. Unbelievable."

Jill was appalled. "You are going to live the good life up here and leave your poor mother behind? Doesn't she deserve better than that?"

"Oh, geesh, don't you think I haven't hashed that out in my brain? She's better off without me. I never could do anything right. Besides, she could never make it up that beanstalk. And I don't wanna go back to living a poor life again."

"Okay," said Detective Crown. "If we can find a way to get her up here, and you stayed here the entire time, would that suit you fine?"

Bean grinned, his eyes twinkled. "I'd be forever grateful, sir. Hey, don't I know you from somewhere? You look familiar."

1421.content:
The three walked through market, looking around for anyone who could tell them where Jake had gone when he'd left the market. Seven loud voices to their right made them stop and look to see who was causing the ruckus. Jack, Jill and their new friend waded through the crowd to see if maybe the dwarfs had any information for them. The seven were arguing in front of a stand selling apples of all varieties.

"Those aren't any good, Doc, we should get some red ones!" Grumpy mumbled.

"But it was a red apple that poisoned Snow White!" Doc replied and grabbed several green apples.

"Well, excuse me, um, but the poison apple was one-of-a-kind, I think." Bashful tried to insert his opinion in the conversation. All seven of them looked rather forlorn and disheveled, even Happy. Sleepy wasn't the only one who looked exhausted, either. The shop keeper was eying them all uncertainly, obviously wondering whether he should sell them any apples at all.

"Gentlemen, is there a disagreement?" Jill asked politely, but loudly. Dopey gave her a lopsided grin.

"Well, yes, m'lady." Doc gave her a small bow. "We're not used to buying food, Snow White always did it for us! And apples are so hard for us to buy, after, well, you know, but we love apple pie!"

Jill considered the dilemma for a moment. "You could just buy the apple pies fresh." She turned to their new friend. "Is there a baker in the market who sells apple pies?"

"Of course!" he replied. "There's one just down--"

"AAAAACHOOOOOO!" Sneezy sniffed, "I'm so sorry, the flowers really bother my allergies." He indicated the stall next to them.

"--the other end of this road." He finished.

"Oh yes," Jack put in, "those pies are delicious, you really ought to try them. But before you hurry off, have you seen Jack the Beanstalk climber recently?" He showed them the picture.

Doc looked at the picture for a moment. "I think we saw him in our neck of the Woods the other day, didn't we, boys?"

Grumpy snorted. "That wasn't him, the kid we saw was younger."

"No, no, that's definitely him," Sleepy yawned.

"How would you know, you were sleeping!" Grumpy retorted.

The three detectives decided it was best to leave the dwarfs to their own devices and head off in search of Jack. The other Jack rubbed his stomach, "You know, talking about those apple pies made me hungry. Maybe we could go get some and see if anyone else has seen Jack."
